title: Shares in Mediaset jump after deal with Sky Italia
text:
April 3, 2018 / 7:33 AM / Updated 27 minutes ago Shares in Mediaset jump after deal with Sky Italia Reuters Staff 1 Min Read 
MILAN (Reuters) - Shares in Italy’s Mediaset ( MS.MI ) rose more than 7 percent on Tuesday, four days after the Italian broadcaster signed a content deal with Sky’s ( SKYB.L ) Italian unit, paving the way for a possible sale of part of its pay-TV business to Sky. FILE PHOTO: The Mediaset tower in Cologno Monzese, near Milan, Italy, April 8, 2016. REUTERS/Stefano Rellandini/File Photo 
Mediaset’s struggling Premium pay-TV business, once attractive to customers for its soccer channel offer, will stop airing matches at the end of June, when its rights to broadcast the Champions League expire. 
The business has changed its strategy towards on-demand offerings and away from expensive, premium sports content after a deal to sell it to France’s Vivendi ( VIV.PA ), signed in April 2016, fell through three months later. 
The French media group now holds just under 30 percent of Mediaset and is entangled in a legal row with the Italian broadcaster. Reporting by Giulia Segreti and Francesca Landini; editing by John Stonestreet
